abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We describe a novel type of ribosomopathy that is defined by deficiency in diphthamidylation of translation elongation factor 2. The ribosomopathy was identified by correlating phenotypes and biochemical properties of previously described patients with diphthamide biosynthesis gene 1 (<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>) deficiencies with a new patient that carried inactivating mutations in both alleles of the human diphthamide biosynthesis gene 2 (<jats:italic>DPH2</jats:italic>). The human<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with developmental delay, abnormal head circumference (microcephaly or macrocephaly), short stature, and congenital heart disease. It is defined by variants with reduced functionality of the<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>gene observed so far predominantly in consanguineous homozygous patients carrying identical mutant alleles of<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>. Here we report a child with a very similar phenotype carrying biallelic variants of the human<jats:italic>DPH2</jats:italic>. The gene products DPH1 and DPH2 are components of a heterodimeric enzyme complex that mediates the first step of the posttranslational diphthamide modification on the nonredundant eukaryotic translation elongation factor 2 (eEF2). Diphthamide deficiency was shown to reduce the accuracy of ribosomal protein biosynthesis. Both DPH2 variants described here severely impair diphthamide biosynthesis as demonstrated in human and yeast cells. This is the first report of a patient carrying compound heterozygous DPH2 loss-of-function variants with a<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>syndrome-like phenotype and implicates diphthamide deficiency as the root cause of this patient’s clinical phenotype as well as of<jats:italic>DPH1</jats:italic>-syndrome. These findings define “diphthamide-deficiency syndrome” as a special ribosomopathy due to reduced functionality of components of the cellular machinery for eEF2-diphthamide synthesis.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: KM and UB are members of and employed by Roche Pharma Research & Early Development. Roche is interested in targeted therapies and diagnostics. ST and JS are employed by Blueprint Genetics. Blueprint Genetics is interested in genetic testing including identification and correlation of genetic variants with human diseases. All other authors declare no conflict of interest.
